titleStmt.title: Despatch from John H. Smyth to John Hay, June 30, 1881

bibl.title: Despatch from John H. Smyth to John Hay
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p:
Consulate General of the United States,
Monrovia, Liberia, June 30, 1881.

Mr. J. H. Smyth to the
Assistant Secretary of State

Consulate General of the United States,
Monrovia, Liberia, June 30, 1881.
I have the honor to forward the within quarterly returns, for the quarter ending June 30, 1881.
In connection with the returns for the quarter ending March 21, 1881, I made allusion to the arrival of the bark "Tuck Sing' of the house of Fowler, Crampton & Co., New York.

On investigation I found the vessel to have been foreign built, and owned by foreigners, and as a consequence I do not report the arrival nor the departure. Also
Hon. John Hay,
Assistant Secretary,
Washington, D.C.
Also, the bark Horace Scudder of Boston, an American vessel, arrived, but did not enter formerly, and did not become liable for fees.
Please find return enclosures as follows: letters and despatches received, #1; letters sent, #2; arrivals and departures of American vessels, #3; digest of the invoice book, #4.

I am, Sir,
Your obedient servant,
Jno. H. Smyth, U.S.
Consul General.

1. Letters and despatches received.
2 Letters sent.
3 Arrivals and departures of American vessels.
4 Digest of the invoice book.
